question:

Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

A) Mon. morning: Helen; Mon. afternoon: Robert Tues. morning: Olivia; Tues. afternoon: Irving Wed. morning: Lenore; Wed. afternoon: Kyle
B) Mon. morning: Irving; Mon. afternoon: Olivia Tues. morning: Helen; Tues. afternoon: Kyle Wed. morning: Nina; Wed. afternoon: Lenore
C) Mon. morning: Lenore; Mon. afternoon: Helen Tues. morning: George; Tues. afternoon: Kyle Wed. morning: Robert; Wed. afternoon: Irving
D) Mon. morning: Nina; Mon. afternoon: Helen Tues. morning: Robert; Tues. afternoon: Irving Wed. morning: Olivia; Wed. afternoon: Lenore
E) Mon. morning: Olivia; Mon. afternoon: Nina Tues. morning: Irving; Tues. afternoon: Helen Wed. morning: Kyle; Wed. afternoon: George
chain_of_thought: George can only speak on Tuesday, and neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. Option A fails because Olivia gives an afternoon report. Option B fails because George cannot give a report on Monday and Robert cannot give an afternoon report. Option C fails because George gives a report on Tuesday. Option D fails because Robert gives a report on Monday and Olivia gives a report on Wednesday. Option E does not violate any conditions and satisfies the given conditions, so it could be the schedule of the students' reports.
full_output:
<think>George can only speak on Tuesday, and neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. Option A fails because Olivia gives an afternoon report. Option B fails because George cannot give a report on Monday and Robert cannot give an afternoon report. Option C fails because George gives a report on Tuesday. Option D fails because Robert gives a report on Monday and Olivia gives a report on Wednesday. Option E does not violate any conditions and satisfies the given conditions, so it could be the schedule of the students' reports.</think>

Each solo will be either a modern piece or a traditional piece. The choice of pianist and type of piece for the solos must conform to the following conditions: The third solo is a traditional piece. Exactly two of the traditional pieces are performed consecutively. In the fourth solo, either Wayne performs a traditional piece or Zara performs a modern piece. The pianist who performs the second solo does not perform the fifth solo. No traditional piece is performed until Wayne performs at least one modem piece.

Which one of the following could be all of the solos that are traditional pieces?
A) the first, third, and fourth
B) the second, third, and fourth
C) the third and fourth
D) the third and fifth
E) the fourth and fifth
chain_of_thought: Since no traditional piece is performed until Wayne performs at least one modern piece, the first two solos must be modern. The third solo is traditional, and since exactly two traditional pieces are performed consecutively, the fourth and fifth solos must also be traditional. The fourth solo has the condition that either Wayne performs a traditional piece or Zara performs a modern piece, but since the fourth and fifth solos are both traditional, this condition is satisfied. The pianist who performs the second solo does not perform the fifth solo, and since the second and fifth solos are modern and traditional respectively, this condition is also satisfied. Therefore, the only option that could be all of the solos that are traditional pieces is D, the third and fifth.
full_output:
<think>Since no traditional piece is performed until Wayne performs at least one modern piece, the first two solos must be modern. The third solo is traditional, and since exactly two traditional pieces are performed consecutively, the fourth and fifth solos must also be traditional. The fourth solo has the condition that either Wayne performs a traditional piece or Zara performs a modern piece, but since the fourth and fifth solos are both traditional, this condition is satisfied. The pianist who performs the second solo does not perform the fifth solo, and since the second and fifth solos are modern and traditional respectively, this condition is also satisfied. Therefore, the only option that could be all of the solos that are traditional pieces is D, the third and fifth.</think>
<ans>D</ans>

question:
A realtor will show a prospective buyer seven houses—J, K, L, M, N, 0, and P—during a single day. The first and second houses to be shown will be shown in the morning; the third, fourth, and fifth houses to be shown will be shown in the afternoon; the sixth and seventh houses to be shown will be shown in the evening. The houses will be shown according to the following rules: J must be shown in the evening. K cannot be shown in the morning. L must be shown at some time after K is shown and at some time before M is shown.

Which one of the following could be the order, from first through seventh, in which the realtor shows the houses?
A) K, 0, L, M, N, J, P
B) N, L, P, K, M, 0, J
C) 0, P, K, L, N, M, J
D) 0, P, M, N, K, L, J
E) P, 0, K, J, L, N, M
chain_of_thought: K can’t be in the morning, so eliminate options A and E. J is in the evening, so eliminate options B and D. L is after K and before M. In option C, K is third, L is fifth, and M is sixth, so it satisfies all conditions.
full_output:
<think>K can’t be in the morning, so eliminate options A and E. J is in the evening, so eliminate options B and D. L is after K and before M. In option C, K is third, L is fifth, and M is sixth, so it satisfies all conditions.</think>
<ans>C</ans>

question:
Exactly five witnesses—Franco, Garcia, Hong, Iturbe, and Jackson—are to be scheduled to testify at a hearing that is to take exactly three days of one week—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Each witness testifies on exactly one day of the hearing. The schedule must meet the following conditions: Franco does not testify on the same day that Garcia testifies. Iturbe testifies on Wednesday. Exactly two witnesses testify on Tuesday. Hong does not testify on Monday. At least one witness testifies on Monday.

Which one of the following is an acceptable schedule of witnesses?
A) Monday: Franco Tuesday: Hong and Iturbe Wednesday: Garcia and Jackson
B) Monday: Franco and Hong Tuesday: Iturbe and Jackson Wednesday: Garcia
C) Monday: Garcia Tuesday: Franco and Iturbe Wednesday: Hong and Jackson
D) Monday: Garcia and Jackson Tuesday: Franco and Hong Wednesday: Iturbe
E) Monday: Garcia and Jackson Tuesday: Hong Wednesday: Franco and Iturbe
chain_of_thought: Iturbe is on Wednesday, and exactly two witnesses are on Tuesday. This means Hong and Iturbe are on Tuesday, as Garcia and Franco cannot be on the same day. Garcia and Franco must be on Monday and Wednesday, and the only option that satisfies this condition is B, as Garcia is on Monday, Franco is on Wednesday, and Hong and Iturbe are on Tuesday.
full_output:
<think>Iturbe is on Wednesday, and exactly two witnesses are on Tuesday. This means Hong and Iturbe are on Tuesday, as Garcia and Franco cannot be on the same day. Garcia and Franco must be on Monday and Wednesday, and the only option that satisfies this condition is B, as Garcia is on Monday, Franco is on Wednesday, and Hong and Iturbe are on Tuesday.</think>
<ans>B</ans>

chain_of_thought: The western must start before the horror film. The romance cannot be on screen 2, and the sci-fi film cannot be on screen 3. The horror and mystery films are on different screens. D has the western before the horror, romance not on screen 2, sci-fi not on screen 3, and the horror and mystery on different screens, so it satisfies all conditions.

Exactly three of the workers will be selected to be project members, and exactly one of these project members will be the project leader. The selection is subject to the following constraints: Quinn or Ruiz can be a project member only if leading the project. If Smith is a project member, Taylor must also be. If Wells is a project member, neither Ruiz nor Verma can be.

Verma could be the project leader if which one of the following is true?
A) Neither Quinn nor Smith is selected.
B) Neither Ruiz nor Taylor is selected.
C) Neither Smith nor Taylor is selected.
D) Neither Smith nor Xue is selected.
E) Neither Taylor nor Wells is selected.
chain_of_thought: For Verma to be the leader, Quinn and Ruiz cannot be selected since they must lead, and Smith and Taylor cannot be selected since they must be together. So eliminate options A and D since they include at least one of Smith or Taylor. Option C eliminates Smith but not Taylor, so it doesn’t work. Option B eliminates Ruiz but not Smith, so it doesn’t work. Option E eliminates Taylor and Wells, so it does work.
full_output:
<think>For Verma to be the leader, Quinn and Ruiz cannot be selected since they must lead, and Smith and Taylor cannot be selected since they must be together. So eliminate options A and D since they include at least one of Smith or Taylor. Option C eliminates Smith but not Taylor, so it doesn’t work. Option B eliminates Ruiz but not Smith, so it doesn’t work. Option E eliminates Taylor and Wells, so it does work.</think>
<ans>E</ans>
